commentBody: One of the definitions of HOST is a literal army: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/host Entry #4, def. 2. So it doesn't have to be metaphorical at all.

After yesterday's Tuesday, this was a themeless Wednesday.
Fine if you aren't interested in a challenge.

Pleasant construction, wrong venue.

IMO
Beat the last record by 35 seconds.  New record 10.44.

For people who like having their MTWRFSS in order from slowest to fastest: remember when that unusually easy Saturday came around on July 1, 2023?  I never thought I'd beat my time there on a Friday puzzle.

Until today.  

Now I just have to figure out how to do a Thursday even faster than this.

Nothing objectionable, but nothing too remarkable, and as Barry said a little on the easy side. My only disappointment is that the brilliant Pedro ALMODOVAR is much better known as a director, I think, than a screenwriter. Maybe the Oscar win was highlighted to justify his importance to the “why should I have heard of some foreign director” crowd; if so that’s a shame.

I breezed through this one, although it didn’t feel especially easy.  I thought the the clues for BALLOONANIMAL and SENTINEL (spelling on that one looks funny to me) were nice.  I misspelled ALMODOVAR, but self corrected before completing the puzzle, so for once I didn’t have to hunt out my mistake(s) after filling in the last square.

For anyone unfamiliar with Bon IVER (pronounced like a winter greeting in French), the first two albums, For Emma Forever Ago and Bon Iver, are lovely.  I haven’t kept up with the band since then.
This marks 1,000 days of my daily crossword streak!! Wahoo!!!
I need to stop doing the Friday puzzle while watching the new episode of "And Just Like That." It's bringing down my average...

Nice puzzle, but I shouldn't be able to finish a theme-less Friday in under 9 minutes. There have been quite a few breezy late week puzzles lately. I think it's an issue of clueing. The fill on these puzzles does satisfy, but I think I should have to work a little harder to get them.

The puzzle was fine but have all the puzzles the last week or two been unusually easy?  Other than misspelling Almodovar's name I pretty much breezed through this...

Oh well, a good debut for the constructor.  Congratulations.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

"You listen to sounds of balloons exploding?"
"Yeah, I love pop music!"

(These puns went from bad to burst.)

Pedro. I love his work, so character driven, colorful. And Salma Hayek was the star of one (All About My Mother) and appeared in others of his in the 1980s-90s. She's just as impressive as Pedro, her range, how game she is to try new roles, and how much game she has. Good to see 'em together here. Pedro, Bard of the post-telenovela world of thwarted dreams and sudden triumphs. 

Deuce indeed. It's good to be alive in this era of sports, if anyone saw the Anisimova-Sabalenka duel today. Lotta deuces, and some good magic. 

And I thought he was BORN Iggy Pop! The name fit him like a glove.
Mini was harder
That was shockingly fast. I beat my Friday PB and it wasn’t even close. It helped that I nailed ALMODOVAR and a couple other potential trivia traps right off the top of my head, but still.

Had to dig around a bit figure out HOSTS x OARED

I eventually got there, but I kept passing over it — I guess  picturing a shell with four ears and thinking HeST was a “Friday level” word for an army. 

Don’t expect NASA will be calling anytime soon.
I very much enjoyed this puzzle, and though it is no fault of the entries, the cluing is too easy. I agree with others who feel that the Friday puzzle should be something you can dig your teeth into.

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. McCarron! The fill was entertaining and I especially liked the clue for BALLOON ANIMAL (it’s hard to believe that that answer has never before been in a NYT puzzle).

I hope we’ll see you back here soon!
The film star's name doesn't consist of two presidents. It consists of two presidents' names.

As someone who doesn't care even a little bit about solving speed, I enjoyed the smoothly elegant fill of this puzzle. 

I have the timer turned off in settings, but I really wish I could prevent the app from displaying the completion and average times. I do the crossword to pass the time, not to beat the clock.

HARRISON FORD and Pedro ALMODOVAR in the same puzzle? Be still my beating heart.  And it's nice to see so many others familiar with Pedro's work.
And for those of you whose spidey sense was tingling when filling in BALLOON ANIMAL, it was just last Friday that we had BALLOON dog.
Fun puzzle, congrats on the 1st NYT puzzle!

I'm pretty sure there are going to be some crusty comments about how easy the puzzle is, despite there being some clues that are not what they seemed to be, but I'm fine with it.  It was interesting and often funny, and I would have been happier if it had been a little more of each, but not every Friday needs to make us tear our hair out.  

I'm a fan of both Almodovar and Ford, so they were easy fills, and names I didn't know I got with the crosses (had to google to confirm that I didn't have a bad RAPP), but there were a lot of names.  Should we anticipate a puzzle in the near future that will be all proper names, with maybe a couple of Oreos and urns for glue? 

James, I don't mean to be mean—you construct the puzzle, but the editors choose the day—and you did your part commendably.  I think we were just expecting it to be tougher.  Thank you, and come again soon.

The clue for BALLOONANIMAL was nice, and the fill was overall quite solid.

But this was Tuesday/Wednesday level of difficulty.

A shame.

4/10.

The trend goes on.

The puzzle was fine, no complaints at all.

But it was also fairly easy.

And the easier they get, the worse I am at solving them.  This time it was ALMODaVAR and aNO.

I'm going to go bash my head against the wall a few times.  Maybe that will help.

Anyone else read the film star with two presidential names clue and immediately think Andrew Garfield instead of HARRISON FORD? 

Too long obviously, but it does make me wonder exactly how many stars/celebrities could fit that clue. Fun little mental exercise.

Beat my Friday PB pretty handily (7:58, which I’m sure I’ll be told are rookie numbers by the veterans of the Wordplay comments section). I wasn’t surprised to come here and learn many folks found this a tad too easy, but I’m not mad about it in the slightest. The grid was well constructed and had some fun trivia sprinkled in — love to see Almodovar getting some love!

HOSTS as the answer for [Armies] made me think of the phrase "And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly HOST praising God, and saying..." From the Gospel of Luke, but I really know it from "A Charlie Brown Christmas", and from Handel's "Messiah ". A Charlie Brown Christmas https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=bPhqMJpQsYQ&t=1m20s Messiah https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=GbicfvN4zFM&t=46m04s

workAHEAD before READAHEAD
rioT before HOOT
Era before EON
AonE (A-onE) before ACME
DarnS before DRATS

Misplaced confidence in the first guess does tend to slow one down.

On a different subject - does anybody using the Android app see their stats anywhere? If so, how do I find them?  

According to the Gameplay newsletter from July 7, stats will soon be added for more games, and that "The contents will be familiar to those who are already looking at the in-game stats screens", with a sample screen showing crossword stats.

But I've never seen any stats screen anywhere in the app. In-game, outside of the games, my account - just nowhere. So if somebody can tell me where to look, or what button to push, I'd like to know.

Otherwise, I'll just assume that it's another case of Apple-centric thinking, and that the devs don't believe anyone else matters (or exists?) in the gaming community.
My time was halfway between my average and personal best.
HOSTS at 1A is a word often used in the Bible to describe armies.

You don't have to be a race car driver to solve puzzles. They needn't be scored by time as much as the pleasure  of untwisting clues and discovering the mind of the puzzle maker without reading ahead.  A solid challenge involves testing the nuances of English and making intuitional leaps from mere hints to the right answer.  Esoteric references to little known people or books is a sign of weakness either in the clues or in finding a way to put letters in the space.    As much as I have loved Asimov over the decades I never came across ABA.  Why is this acceptable when there are so many clever ways to suggest ABA as an answer? Why use "accouterment" as an acceptable spelling for educated readers?  Nor are queens normally noted for sashes accept in beauty pageants (in which case a better word would be "adornment").  Why should the editors allow rarefied entries like Bon "Iver" when a little effort would come up with a different solution to that area.  The constructor may want to include a nod to a personal favorite, but I find that  a poor excuse for clueless clueing.
This was fun! I loved the clue for Harrison Ford and the whole thing was a good solve.

I was so frustratingly, tantalizingly close to completing the puzzle - which I found very hard but mostly enjoyable - without lookups! Alas, I tripped over the unfamiliar letter salad of BENIHANA.

I filled in the whole grid except for the four squares in the SW corner. I know literally nothing about logarithmic equations, in English or Polish. The "colonial group" clue stumped me, completely, ditto "collar".

So yeah, I looked up the restaurant chain. The final two letters of its name gave me the crosses to deal with that corner of doom.

However, had I actually got those four squares myself, I would still have not received my gold star.

How come?

I had IvS for hookups. There was no indication in the clue that the answer would be an abbreviation, but I've been told dozens of times in these comments, usually by Barry, that some terms, while considered abbreviations initially, became so commonly used over the years they are now words in their own right. I thought IvS fit the bill. BEvIHANA looks no less strange and unfamiliar to me than BANIHANA 🤷.

Ultimately, then, I really did need that one lookup, and I would have needed it (or checking the puzzle) even if math was not my nemesis, and I were smart enough to get the ANTS clue.

BTW, apparently there is one BENIHANA in Warsaw. Food theatrics... Ewww. Not my cup of tea, at all, and neither are chain establishments, in general. There is always something corporately soulless about them.

I found this one to be a breeze! In a fun way.

Since you asked, NYT: I’d love to see the column give background information about some of the trivia-based clues. I rarely find the “tricky clues” section that useful, and I almost never have questions about the clues discussed in that section. But I don’t always know the people referenced in puzzles or important events associated with answers that make them noteworthy. 

As an example, for today’s puzzle: tell me about Pedro Almodovar’s work, the relevance Broadcast.com used to have, Bon Iver’s biggest song, how many Benihanas there are. Not only would I learn something new but these factoids would help me remember the answers for future puzzles (or trivia nights!).
This puzzle screams “some themeless puzzles should run earlier in the week!”

I really must stop coming here immediately after solving in the European early morning. The commentariat is full of the overnight speedy solvers from the US and some of the  bragging is a bit too much for me. 

This was not easy. It was full of trivia that are absolutely not gimmes unless you’re in a particular milieu. It was doable with reasonable effort. It was absolutely not mid week level for me. 

I appreciate that some have to tell that they solved it in single digit minutes. Well done you.

In the role of this forum providing feedback to the NYT folks: crossing IVER with RENEE wasn’t kind 😀

Thanks to the constructor
TIL that we Americans have ruined another word: Accouterment is an accepted spelling.

A quick solve for me, but as I was completing it, I anticipated there would be trouble for some international solvers. I'm betting that later on there will be complaints about PISH. For what it's worth: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pish I've loved ALMODOVAR for decades. My husband and I watched his most recent and first English language film, "The Room Next Door," a few weeks ago. Tilda Swinton, Julianne Moore, and John Turturro are excellent in it. Highly recommended, but be forewarned that the subject matter is pretty heavy. I won't say more. Leaving for our road trip on Saturday, and now I'll be sure to add Bon IVER to my list of albums to listen to during the many hours of driving. Bon Iver was a gimme for me, despite the fact that I've never actually listened to them. (At least, not knowingly.) Fun to see HAI and BENIHANA on opposite sides of the same puzzle.

Nice and easy! I thought it’s Saturday today, and thought it was an extremely easy puzzle for a Saturday. Turns out it’s actually Friday, but it was still quite easy for an end of the week puzzle. 

Re: 33A, I just learned to make a dog last week!
Soo, which country do we think Helsinki is in?

Love a Friday puzzle where I get 1a (hosts) immediately. Felt like the correct answers were just flying off my fingers.Could have gotten better than average except that I typed in Hab instead of Hai (and I knew it was hai) and then had to find my typo. Loved the cluing for Harrison Ford an icon in his own right (Solo, Indiana). Had ivs until I realized Bevihana did not make sense. As a teacher I don’t need syllabus clues to remind me I go back to work in just over 2 weeks.

Regardless of how long it took me to solve the puzzle, i had a great time. It’s a bonus when its a new PB!

Thanks to the constructor, looking forward to many more!

PB for me. No complaints about it being too easy. I taught my son about the difference between a glass half empty and half full today. I may have chugged my proverbial glass on this one, but it was half full of crossword fun going down.

The Hydra was not a sea monster. It was found (legendarily) at Lerna in the Peloponnesus, in a swamp. There is a sea creature, not monstrous, called hydra after the monster, with its multi-headed appearance.

I thought this a fine puzzle for any day of the week. Easy in some spots, challenging in others. Enjoyable throughout.

(Just balancing out the complaints, of which I have none.)
I really enjoyed today's puzzle and was very proud to crush my best Saturday crossword time. Realizing today is Friday was a bit of a let down. I think I'll go back to bed now, it's only 4:40am here.

With a Natick at 26D/A, random phrases (at least one of which could have been clued so many other ways) and far too many entertainment references, pop song lyrics, models, restaurant chains and tech references, this was more like an ad page than a puzzle. 

As to complaints about proper nouns, as I've said before, to me it's not proper nouns in and of themselves, it's the quality of them. Names of capitals, countries, rivers, famous historical figures, literary characters, fine. Those things are worth knowing. Others are just clutter.

On top of all that, this was quite easy even with the numerous things I didn't know and didn't care about. I realize it's just a puzzle and should be fun, but to me this type is just tedious. Strictly my own opinion.

I don’t know supermodels, but somehow
saw the W and my brain filled in the -EK.

Don’t know if Alex is male or female!
How?
Where?
Why was that taking brain space when 
I’ve been trying to remember my neighbor’s
name for at least a year?

I’d like to return some of the useless
stuff living in my noggin, for like,
I dunno,
things I need to know..?

Why?
Is there a number I can call?
Can I speak to a manager?
Oh! Congratulations on your debut James!
Super easy Friday after a quickie Thursday. Don’t know what to expect tomorrow, hoping for some curveballs.

The solvers who knew the cultural references found it too easy and the solvers who didn’t found it too hard. Count me among the former. Fun and breezy puzzle. Renee Rapp is a powerhouse performer and super fun to think about. Here she is in her first number from Mean Girls from the movie, though she also played the role on Broadway: https://youtu.be/D6GENmNRuhQ?si=61FNbc26vwEudqTf To Deb’s question: I feel like there are a HOST of cryptic crosswords tricks that I don’t know. You columnists often explain the ? for the newbs, and there is the ! which means to take the clue literally, e.g. in “It’s a blast!” is not something fun but rather a word that means blast. And the thing is that I think there are other, rarer, more esoteric tricks like that. I would enjoy learning about more of those. Thanks for asking!

Nice puzzle - typical tough Friday for me, but enjoyable working things out from the crosses. And... six debut answers in this one and most of them fairly familiar terms. Surprised to see that. Oh.. and some of those: 

READAHEAD
RACECARDRIVER
GETTINGCLOSER 

And.. even SOLARECLIPSE had never appeared in a Shortz era puzzle before. Surprised at all of that. 

I'll put my puzzle find in a reply. 

...

I'm an old retired fart and could care less what day of the week it is. I work these puzzles strictly for the enjoyment of them and have no idea what my personal best is. Being noncompetitive by nature, I don't really understand the urge to finish a puzzle as fast as possible – it's a pastime to enjoy over coffee and maybe learn a thing or two in the process.

I read INS as physical hook up slots like on the back of a computer or TV- the IN and OUT connections. 

HOSTS also means legion or multitude, so it is a direct, if somewhat archaic, synonym. 

Nice puzzle!
Regarding Deb’s confusion about 1A, HOST can literally mean “army.” No need to rationalized the answer as both being large crowds of people or whatever.

I don’t know how I solved this one without lookups and without knowing half of the Naticks, but I made some educated guesses and they worked out! And I did it three minutes faster than my average of 43:05! 

Editors: in response to your question, I would love some tips for solving the late-week puzzles. It’s rare for me to solve them without lookups.

There ought to be a word for what happened to me a couple of times as I solved.  Where I was stumped by a clue, kept hammering at it with no success, where the crosses weren’t giving the answer away.  Then, in a flash, my brain did see from the crosses the answer that was eluding me, and suddenly that thorny clue made sense, bringing a huge “Hah!”.  That blissful double-barrel-of-discovery Crosslandia moment – is in need of a name!

I liked the Japanese mini-theme, with HAI, YEN, and BENIHANA.  I liked that every answer of the stagger stack in the middle is a NYT debut.  I loved that the clue set was dense with wordplay.  I enjoyed the PuzzPair© of HOOT and OWLY.

Give me “Hah!” moments, likes, and loves, and how can I help but be grateful?  I had a splendid time uncovering this, James, and congratulations on your NYT debut!
Heavenly hosts = Armies of angels. Nice debut!
PB Friday for me too. A lot of my first instincts turned out correct, and many I didn't know were done purely by crosses. Good one, thanks James!

Beat my Friday average, but I wouldn't say this was super easy. (My Thursday and Friday averages are only sixteen seconds apart.)

Never heard of the supermodel (or just about any model, super or otherwise), so when I went back to review 26A I had to see if there was a reference to Beef on WEcK,

Even though the total eclipse was barely a year ago, 5D had me thinking of 3-D movies, not the sky.

And oh, yes! [Insert compulsory objection to any clue for ONO that includes the word "singer".]

Enjoy your Friday, everyone!
There's way too much poorly placed random pop culture trivia.
Shouldn't the clue "Film star whose name consists of two presidents" actually be THREE presidents? William Henry Harrrison, Benjamin Harrison, and Gerald Ford ...
Deb, 1A "Hosts" SEE: https://biblehub.com/luke/2-13.htm
I’d like to see more clues like “Accouterments for a queen,” because I always get a smile from the nitpickers here getting wound up and, usually, refuted.

By my count, 10 H’s, which is a bucketful. Reminded me of the great Nazi novel HHhH, about the assassination of Heydrich. A compelling read. 

tc
Personal best for me today! Was it easier than usual or am I actually getting better at this?

Never heard of the restaurant chain, and assumed that "Hookups" were IVS. So this one defeated me. Will need to make sense of how INS is correct.

OWLY is a horrible word. It's OWLISH. At least we got WHOA and not WOAH.

Another "themeless Wednesday" puzzle. To me, much too gentle for a Friday in the NYT. (He said, after failing to correctly solve the puzzle.)

Not sure that PISH passes the breakfast test, at least according to my Yiddish-speaking grandmother.
Technically that actor is the name of three presidents!

First, a fine debut and, 3 more in the queue?!  Well done. 

Regarding Deb's request for input two thoughts come to mind:

Picking up on Lewis' comment below I'd like to learn more about grid designs, how they are categorized and how is Lewis able to say that this is only the second appearance of today's style?  Is there a database of grid designs somewhere?  

Second, although I've no interest in speed solving myself I would be interested in something along the lines of "Secrets of Crossword Speed Solvers".

Ooohh... and some of the comments led me in a roundabout way to one more puzzle find. A Monday from April 28, 1975. Three 15 letter theme answers in that one, all of them with exactly the same clue: "A first lady." And those three answers: MARYTODDLINCOLN MAMIEEISENHOWER LADYBIRDJOHNSON Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/28/1975&g=50&d=A ....

Just shows what trivia you know matters.  Everyone was crowing yesterday about the puzzle being too easy for a Thursday, and I had to run the alphabet in several places to finally get it right because of a few names.  Whereas this one, despite not remembering how to spell Pedro's last name and only remembering that the Breaking Bad lead's names were alliterative but not what they WERE, fell right into place.  

Delightful puzzle, whether on a Wednesday or a Friday.

This was a good one! Got through it only needing to look up some names - per usual. Got all of the long answers without looking at wordplay. All in all, a great Friday. Better than my average time. Loved it. Hope all have a great weekend! Thanks, Mr. McCarron!

Anyone else think that "What might come with a twist or two" was going to be a cocktail?  I held onto that misguided notion long after I had enough crosses to falsify my initial hypothesis.
Nice misdirect!
I really wanted 1-down to be "Cecil."
Fastest Friday I can remember....
Very first definition in the OED: "An armed company or multitude of men; an army. Now archaic and poetic." (But, I would argue, not at all obscure!)

Oh... and what the heck - one more puzzle find. Don't recall another like this. Anyway - a Tuesday from March 1, 2016 by Freddie Cheng. Some theme-related answers in that one, though they were all clued straightforwardly: EVENSTEVENS EVELKNIEVEL SEVENELEVEN PETPEEVES NEVERMIND And there were some others. And then the 'reveal': "1950 Bette Davis film hinting at something found 15 times in this puzzle" ALLABOUTEVE Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/1/2016&g=44&d=A ....

My fastest Friday ever: 8:13!
Seemed a little easy for a Friday, definitely more of a Tuesday-Wednesday level, so it seems like it was placed on a Friday just for being themeless and having long (but easy) spans.
I never thought I'd be the person who says "I might be done with the NYT crossword" ... but I might be. Getting Wednesday-level puzzles on Fridays is becoming all too common.

Today's photo accompanying the "Wordplay" column shows Yulia Nestsiarenka of Belarus winning the women's 100 meters final at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens.  It's a great photograph.

An interesting fact:  Nestsiarenka is the only white woman to win this race at the Olympics since 1980.

There are already 215 Comments, and the first two I see are bemoaning the too-easy solve...  PISH-TOSH (I say you can't have one without the other!)
I'm supposed to know "Mean Girls", Katy Perry songs, the meaning of Phanerozoic, a supermodel, and dot-com bubble cannibals, and a Bon who's not JOVI?  AND a screenwriter????  Sheesh.

Yes, I completed the puzzle,  I found it challenging.  
(Is BENIHANA still in business?)  
I did enjoy the tricky clues like "Tales are related about them" and "Please, take this off my hands"....  but I believe OWLY belongs in the list of "desperation entries" requiring a rewrite.

Honestly, the puzzles lately are letting me know how old I am. If you're going to rely so heavily on pop culture, at least spread it around so that those of us who are over 50 and don't spend most of our time watching TV, going to the movies and listening to top 40 music have a fighting chance to solve the puzzle without having to resort to internet searches. And ease up on using clues with quotes, "?" and "say" to create such tortured clues. That said, some of the clues in today's puzzle are quite clever.

I just looked up the year that MURDER AT THE ABA was published and it was 1976 -- so I was running the Mystery Guild Bool Club, which I ran from 1974 to 1974 at the time.  And I can't remember if I took it as a Selection or not.  I must have -- Asimov was a big name at the time, though not in the mystery genre.  The title and premise were amusing -- the ABA, which often hosted terrific publishing events, was well-known to us publishing types and we were therefore being promised an "insider's" murder mystery.  But I'm pretty sure the book was a dud, because had it been good, I would have remembered it. I needed crosses to get ABA in the puzzle today.

My biggest hiccup today: I had the W from WHOA (7D) and wrote in "aWed" for "big-eyed in a way."  Thank you, OGDEN Nash (one of my faves) for getting me to OWLY -- which I don't like very much.  I like AWED much more.

Also had to wait to see if it would be SOLAR, LUNAR or TOTAL ECLIPSE.

Not terribly hard for a Friday -- but very engrossing, I thought.  Liked it.

Oh noooo, dreadful corporate lingo makes its way into the Times in the form of 17A!

The constructors make up for it with 5D, which I am taking as a tribute to a certain highly anticipated album that is dropping today.  Happy CLIPSE day, everyone.

I am on the side of those that found the puzzle easy, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.

I thought “alternative to French” was clever. Alek Wek is a bit obscure, I think, but her name is so great, I enjoyed the reminder, and am sure I will be repeating it throughout the day.
You can please some of the solvers some of the time, but never all of the solvers all of the time.
Easy Friday

Maybe something we can all get on board with is not liking the new graphic for the crossword stats. 

You can’t easily compare this week to your average from the graph. Especially since the axis changes.
Maybe i'm missing something, but the 1952 Olympics were in Helsinki, Finland, not Norway.
Not too difficult but there were some good misdirects

Looks like I'm not alone in getting a PB today. Most of the long answers came easily and the trivia was in my wheelhouse. I kept thinking I'd reach a section that would stop me in my tracks for a while like usual, but it never happened. Just a slight delay to get the B in ABA. 

Funny how hip hop lyrics sometimes help me with the crossword. They are often dense with pop culture references. This one from the song "Putting Shame in Your Game" helped today:

I'm the Benihana chef on the SP12
I chop the f out the beats left on the shelf

(FYI, The SP12 is a drum machine/sampler, and "chop" means to mix beats.)
ashamed of how long it took me to find "ENO" to "ONO" to get my gold star today
"Though an host should encamp against me, my heart shall not fear: though war should rise against me, in this will I be confident." Psalm 27 3, KJV.

In contrast to many of today’s solvers, I found this one to be a challenge. I was almost 29 minutes over my average time.  Having said that, I found it to be a very enjoyable.  Lots of good clues and misdirects and nothing that I would say is unfair. Good puzzle!

Deb Amlen is not qualified to write this column. One literal meaning of the word 'host' is army. It has nothing to do with the fact that both can be used figuratively to refer to a large group of people. This is embarrassing for the Wordplay column. The NYT should hire someone who is capable of understanding crosswords to write this column.
Is it Tuesday? It must be Tuesday and a breezy one at that. Seriously friends. Go ahead in the archives and do this week's Friday from 2015. Then tell me these are not becoming exponentially easier.

As others have noted, this was not a particularly difficult Friday puzzle. For me, as one of the world's oldest "Star Wars" fans, the 21-Down clue was a real treat! And may the Force (Ford?) be with all of you!
Really liked the clue for 21D: Film star whose name consists of two presidents.  Why did I never notice that!?

Natick hell, but there weren't many options.

Weird combo -- lots of obscure proper names but not a terribly difficult puzzle overall.
A solid, steady Friday puzzle. I really enjoyed it, though OWLY gets a side-eye from me...
First Friday ever that I got through without needing any help (except for looking up the definition of accouterment). Yay, loved this one. It’s so satisfying when you figure out the grid spanners
1952 Olympics were held in Helsinki, FINland.

Every now and then I am on the same wavelength as the constructor.  Today I got my personal best and it was about 1/3 of my average.  I had a good night's sleep and a clear brain.  I didn't try to rush, but everything just fell into place.  I'm nowhere near single digit time.
Clue 1 across -- AIDS is the syndrome.  Aides are helpful things.

Today's crossword was the first Friday I've solved without help! I'd like to believe my brain suddenly expanded, but I suspect its a much easier puzzle than most Fridays.  I'm still taking the win !  Thank you, I needed that today.

The rats called. They admit to having nests that are entanglements of various materials, and idiomatically so. But they would like to point out that, while places infested by their kind are often considered to be dirty, their nests per se have not typically been likened filth-wise to the homes of pigs.

And my mother called (from beyond) to assure me she never thought my hair was a sty.

In Canada, when I was young, Ranch wasn’t an option. We had to take French.

Nice puzzle.

Nice debut, James, a good chewy Friday puzzle.

@John

Well, I’d agree, except that the clue doesn’t specify that we’re looking for the eponymous Hydra from Greek mythology. You are correct: Greek myth lacks a canonical sea serpent figure akin to, say, Norse mythology (hello, Midgard Serpent). Hydra of Lerna is a singular, chthonic, freshwater monster—deadly but definitively non-marine. Her name (ὕδρα) is etymologically related to “water” (ὕδωρ), but functionally a proper noun. There’s no plural or generic use in Classical Greek—to Euripides, Pindar, et al., Hydra is the Hydra. Even as late as  the 2nd c. CE Bibliotheca, Pseudo-Apollodorus summarizes very matter-of-factly how Heracles dispatches her: monster, marsh, many heads, cauterized stumps. 

But then from Late Antiquity into the Middle Ages there’s a semantic shift. If you look at the Hydra in Aberdeen or Cambridge bestiaries, Christian morality seeps into the text and the Hydra is now more allegorical. Also, the illustrations start placing her in a marine setting. The serpent imagery is absorbed into Christian theology: serpent = Satan; multiple heads = persistent sin; water = baptismal or apocalyptic terrain. Now “hydra” officially breaks free of the Greek marsh and starts moonlighting as a generalized sea monster/symbol of sin. The texts are now less interested in mythic canon and more in moral allegory—fertile ground for semantic creep.

Fast forward a few more centuries and today hydra (lower-case h) is indeed a [sea serpent of myth]. 

(Just not Greek myth.)

I suppose you’re mentioning this factoid in light of yesterday’s discussion about “race”. 

In fact, it’s a logical fallacy to conclude that because a preponderance of people who happen to have darker skin tones tend to excel at certain athletics, that every person who shares that skin tone is also similarly gifted or that those without that skin tone are doomed to mediocrity. 

Similarly, we would not conclude that since the vast majority of chess Grandmasters are men with lighter skin tones, that one must necessarily be a white man in order to excel at chess or that every white man is predisposed towards chess greatness. 

What is most likely at work is genetic tendencies in regional populations, not genetic tendencies tied directly to skin tone. Kenya, famously, produces the world’s most marathon winners. It would be inaccurate to say that most Africans, broadly, win the most marathons. 

Grouping people according to skin tone is arbitrary and causes much more harm than good. There are much more relevant ways of looking at differences in populations: I’d say first and foremost social-economic factors. 

Cheers!

Asimov was also a noted mystery author and a frequent contributor to Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine.
